maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves performance metrics on an I/O flow that is monitored by Storage QoS.

The Get-StorageQoSFlow cmdlet retrieves performance metrics on an I/O flow that is monitored by Storage Quality of Service (Storage QoS). The metrics are throughput and latency averages, computed over a 5-minute rolling time interval.

Each file handle opened by a server that runs Hyper-V to a VHD or VHDX file is considered a flow. If a virtual machine has two virtual hard disks attached, it will have 1 flow to the file server cluster per file. If a VHDX is shared with multiple virtual machines, it will have 1 flow per virtual machine.
For more information about Storage QoS, see Storage Quality of Service in Windows Server Technical Preview (https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Mt126108).
Specifies the GUID that identifies the flow. This identifier is not unique across flow objects, because the same logical flow may be split across several volumes or storage nodes.
Identifies the virtual machine that is the initiator of the flow.
Specifies the path of the file that a flow accesses.
Specifies the ID of a volume that the flow accesses.
Specifies the friendly name of the initiator.
Specifies the hostname of the node initiating the flow.
Specifies the hostname of the storage node servicing the flow.

Specifies the status of the flow.
-- Ok indicates that the flow meets the minimum Input/Output Operations Per Second (IOPS). -- InsufficientThroughput indicates that the IOPS are below the minimum.
Indicates that this cmdlet includes the default flow, which groups together all flows not governed by a policy.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies a policy for which to get associated flows.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the path of the file that a flow accesses.
Specifies the GUID that identifies the flow. This identifier is not unique across flow objects, because the same logical flow may be split across several volumes or storage nodes.
Indicates that this cmdlet includes the default flow, which groups together all flows not governed by a policy.
Identifies the virtual machine that is the initiator of the flow.
Specifies the friendly name of the initiator.
Specifies the hostname of the node initiating the flow.
Specifies a policy for which to get associated flows.

Specifies the status of the flow.
-- Ok indicates that the flow meets the minimum Input/Output Operations Per Second (IOPS). -- InsufficientThroughput indicates that the IOPS are below the minimum.
Specifies the hostname of the storage node servicing the flow.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the ID of a volume that the flow accesses.
This cmdlet outputs a Common Information Model (CIM) object of type MSFT_StorageQoSFlow (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/mt164591(v=vs.815).aspx).

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get information on an I/O flow
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-StorageQoSFlow -FilePath "C:\ClusterStorage\Volume01\TEST"
InitiatorName FilePath InitiatorIOPS InitiatorLatency PSComputerName
------------- -------- ------------- ---------------- --------------
storqosclient C:\ClusterStorage\Volume01\TEST 104 8.0921
storqosclient C:\ClusterStorage\Volume01\TEST 31 8.9741

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets information about all flow initiators accessing C:\ClusterStorage\Volume01\TEST.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the object representing the policy store, which contains global QoS settings.
The Get-StorageQosPolicyStore cmdlet gets the object representing the policy store, which contains global Quality of Service (QoS) settings.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
This cmdlet returns the object representing the policy store, which contains global QoS settings.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get the object representing the policy store

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the object representing the policy store with verbose output.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a storage QoS policy from the policy manager.
The Get-StorageQosPolicy cmdlet retrieves a storage Quality of Service (QoS) policy from the storage QoS Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) provider.
For more information about Storage QoS, see Storage Quality of Service in Windows Server Technical Preview (https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Mt126108).
Specifies a child policy, for which to retrieve a parent policy. If the ChildPolicy parameter is specified, this cmdlet retrieves any parent policy associated with the input object.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the policy, or a wildcard pattern.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the GUID of the policy.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies a parent policy for which to retrieve child policies. If the ParentPolicy parameter is specified, this cmdlet retrieves all of the child policies associated with the input object.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies a flow object. If the Flow parameter is specified, this cmdlet retrieves the policy governing the flow input object, if any.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies a child policy, for which to retrieve a parent policy. If the ChildPolicy parameter is specified, this cmdlet retrieves any parent policy associated with the input object.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies a flow object. If the Flow parameter is specified, this cmdlet retrieves the policy governing the flow input object, if any.
Specifies the name of the policy, or a wildcard pattern.
Specifies a parent policy for which to retrieve child policies. If the ParentPolicy parameter is specified, this cmdlet retrieves all of the child policies associated with the input object.
Specifies the GUID of the policy.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
This cmdlet outputs a Common Information Model (CIM) object of type MSFT_StorageQoSPolicy (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/mt164592(v=vs.85).aspx).

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get a QoS policy by name
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-StorageQosPolicy -Name "Policy01"
Name MinimumIops MaximumIops Status
---- ----------- ----------- ------
Policy01 10 100 Ok

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the QoS policy named Policy01.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get a parent QoS policy
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-StorageQosPolicy -ChildPolicy (Get-StorageQosPolicy -Name "Policy02")
Name MinimumIops MaximumIops Status
---- ----------- ----------- ------
Policy01 10 100 Ok

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the parent policy of the policy named Policy02. If there are hierarchical policies, the hierarchy can be traversed using -ChildPolicy and -ParentPolicy.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves per-volume performance metrics on a volume that is monitored by Storage QoS.

The Get-StorageQosVolume cmdlet retrieves per-volume storage performance metrics on a volume that services Storage Quality of Service (Storage QoS) flows. The metrics are throughput and latency averages, aggregated over all flows, and computed over a 5-minute rolling time interval.

Each file handle opened by a server that runs Hyper-V to a VHD or VHDX file is considered a flow. If a virtual machine has two virtual hard disks attached, it has 1 flow to the file server cluster per file. If a VHDX is shared with multiple virtual machines, it has 1 flow per virtual machine.
For more information about Storage QoS, see Storage Quality of Service in Windows Server Technical Preview (https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Mt126108).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the file system path of a volume.
Specifies the status of flows on a volume. -- Ok indicates the minimum IOPS are being met. -- InsufficientThroughput indicates IOPS are below minimum.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the ID of a volume that services flows.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the file system path of a volume.
Specifies the status of flows on a volume. -- Ok indicates the minimum IOPS are being met. -- InsufficientThroughput indicates IOPS are below minimum.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the ID of a volume that services flows.
This cmdlet outputs a Common Information Model (CIM) object of type MSFT_StorageQoSVolume (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/mt164596(v=vs.85).aspx).

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get QoS statistics for volumes at a specified path
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Get-StorageQosVolume -Mountpoint "C:\ClusterStorage\*"
Mountpoint IOPS Latency Status
---------- ---- ------- ------
C:\ClusterStorage\Volume01\ 110 18.8469 Ok

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets QoS statistics for all volumes mounted under C:\ClusterStorage.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a Storage QoS policy.
The New-StorageQoSPolicy cmdlet creates a Storage Quality of Service (Storage QoS) policy that specifies the maximum and minimum throughput.
This cmdlet generates the ID of the policy that it creates, if the PolicyId parameter is not specified.
For more information about Storage QoS, see Storage Quality of Service in Windows Server Technical Preview (https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Mt126108).
Specifies the GUID of the policy that this cmdlet creates.
Specifies the name of the policy to create.
Specifies the throughput limit for the policy, in units of 8KB-normalized Input/Output Operations Per Second (IOPS).

Storage usage is measured in normalized IOPS. This is a count of the storage input/output operations per second. Any IO that is 8KB or smaller is considered as one normalized IOPS. Any IO that is larger than 8KB is treated as multiple normalized IOPS. For example, a 256KB request is treated as 32 normalized IOPS.
Specifies the throughput reservation for the policy, in 8KB-normalized IOPS.
Specifies the bandwidth limit for the policy, in bytes per seconds.
Specifies the parent policy of the policy that this cmdlet creates. The object must specify the PolicyId field.

Specifies the type of the policy that this cmdlet creates. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Aggregated and Dedicated. In an aggregated policy, the maximum and minimum throughputs apply to the aggregate throughput of all initiators. In a dedicated policy, the minimum and maximum throughputs apply to each initiator individually.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies the storage QoS Policy that this cmdlet creates in the policy manager. Must be a valid MSFT_StorageQoSPolicy instance that specifies MaximumIops and MinimumIops.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the bandwidth limit for the policy, in bytes per seconds.
Specifies the throughput limit for the policy, in units of 8KB-normalized Input/Output Operations Per Second (IOPS).

Storage usage is measured in normalized IOPS. This is a count of the storage input/output operations per second. Any IO that is 8KB or smaller is considered as one normalized IOPS. Any IO that is larger than 8KB is treated as multiple normalized IOPS. For example, a 256KB request is treated as 32 normalized IOPS.
Specifies the throughput reservation for the policy, in 8KB-normalized IOPS.
Specifies the name of the policy to create.
Specifies the parent policy of the policy that this cmdlet creates. The object must specify the PolicyId field.
Specifies the storage QoS Policy that this cmdlet creates in the policy manager. Must be a valid MSFT_StorageQoSPolicy instance that specifies MaximumIops and MinimumIops.
Specifies the GUID of the policy that this cmdlet creates.

Specifies the type of the policy that this cmdlet creates. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Aggregated and Dedicated. In an aggregated policy, the maximum and minimum throughputs apply to the aggregate throughput of all initiators. In a dedicated policy, the minimum and maximum throughputs apply to each initiator individually.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
This cmdlet outputs a Common Information Model (CIM) object of type MSFT_StorageQoSPolicy (https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/mt164592(v=vs.85).aspx).

The Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (#) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a policy
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>New-StorageQosPolicy -Name "Policy01" -MaximumIops 100 -MinimumIops 10
Name MinimumIops MaximumIops Status
---- ----------- ----------- ------
Policy01 10 100 Ok

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a policy with a maximum of 100 8KB-normalized IOPS and a minimum of 10.

maml:description.maml:para: Deletes a Storage QoS policy from the policy manager.
The Remove-StorageQosPolicy cmdlet deletes a Storage Quality of Service (Storage QoS) policy from the policy manager.
For more information about Storage QoS, see Storage Quality of Service in Windows Server Technical Preview (https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Mt126108).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the name of the policy to be deleted. Accepts wildcard patterns.

Specifies the ID of the policy to be deleted.

Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the name of the policy to be deleted. Accepts wildcard patterns.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove a Storage QoS policy
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-StorageQosPolicy -Name "Policy02" | Remove-StorageQosPolicy
Confirm
Are you sure you want to perform this action?
Performing the operation "DeletePolicy" on target "MSFT_StorageQoSPolicy (PolicyId =
"9db17c75-7c2e-470d-a9a3-b0cf8795babf")".
[Y] Yes [A] Yes to All [N] No [L] No to All [S] Suspend [?] Help (default is "Y"): y

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes a policy named Policy02.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Set the normalized IO to a specified size

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command sets the normalized IO size to 2KB.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies an existing Storage QoS policy.
The Set-StorageQosPolicy cmdlet modifies an existing Storage Quality of Service (Storage QoS) policy.
For more information about Storage QoS, see Storage Quality of Service in Windows Server Technical Preview (https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/Mt126108).
Specifies a new name for the policy.
Specifies the throughput limit for the policy, in units of 8KB-normalized Input/Output Operations Per Second (IOPS).

Storage usage is measured in normalized IOPS. This is a count of the storage input/output operations per second. Any IO that is 8KB or smaller is considered as one normalized IOPS. Any IO that is larger than 8KB is treated as multiple normalized IOPS. For example, a 256KB request is treated as 32 normalized IOPS.
Specifies the throughput reservation for the policy, in 8KB-normalized IOPS.
Specifies the bandwidth limit for the policy, in bytes per second.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the name of the policy to be modified. Accepts wildcard patterns.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies a new name for the policy.
Specifies the throughput limit for the policy, in units of 8KB-normalized Input/Output Operations Per Second (IOPS).

Storage usage is measured in normalized IOPS. This is a count of the storage input/output operations per second. Any IO that is 8KB or smaller is considered as one normalized IOPS. Any IO that is larger than 8KB is treated as multiple normalized IOPS. For example, a 256KB request is treated as 32 normalized IOPS.
Specifies the throughput reservation for the policy, in 8KB-normalized IOPS.
Specifies the bandwidth limit for the policy, in bytes per second.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the policy ID of the policy to be modified.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Specifies a new name for the policy.
Specifies the throughput limit for the policy, in units of 8KB-normalized Input/Output Operations Per Second (IOPS).

Storage usage is measured in normalized IOPS. This is a count of the storage input/output operations per second. Any IO that is 8KB or smaller is considered as one normalized IOPS. Any IO that is larger than 8KB is treated as multiple normalized IOPS. For example, a 256KB request is treated as 32 normalized IOPS.
Specifies the throughput reservation for the policy, in 8KB-normalized IOPS.
Specifies the bandwidth limit for the policy, in bytes per second.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the bandwidth limit for the policy, in bytes per second.
Specifies the throughput limit for the policy, in units of 8KB-normalized Input/Output Operations Per Second (IOPS).

Storage usage is measured in normalized IOPS. This is a count of the storage input/output operations per second. Any IO that is 8KB or smaller is considered as one normalized IOPS. Any IO that is larger than 8KB is treated as multiple normalized IOPS. For example, a 256KB request is treated as 32 normalized IOPS.
Specifies the throughput reservation for the policy, in 8KB-normalized IOPS.
Specifies the name of the policy to be modified. Accepts wildcard patterns.
Specifies a new name for the policy.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies the policy ID of the policy to be modified.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Increase the IOPS limit on a policy

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command increases the IOPS limit on a policy named Policy01 to 200 8KB-normalized IOPS.
